description: From gas (“flammable gaseous hydrocarbon or hydrocarbon mixture used as a fuel”) +‎ light.

nouns.description: gaslight (countable and uncountable, plural gaslights) (Britain, historical)

entries.meaning: A lamp which operates by burning piped illuminating gas (or town gas).
The light produced by the burning gas in such a lamp.

description: From the 1938 stage play Gas Light by the English playwright and novelist Patrick Hamilton (1904–1962), and its 1940 and 1944 film adaptations, in which a husband attempts to convince his wife and others that she is insane by manipulating small elements of their environment. For more details, see also Wikipedia > Gaslighting > Etymology.

verbs.description: gaslight (third-person singular simple present gaslights, present participle gaslighting, simple past and past participle gaslighted or gaslit)

entries.meaning: (chiefly transitive) To manipulate someone such that they doubt their own memory, perceptions of reality, or sanity, typically for malevolent reasons.
examples: Sylvia is a beautiful woman whose business-partner husband is "gaslighting" her. (That means he's trying to drive her crazy.)
